we have with us today actually before i introduce today's speaker i'd like to remind everybody that next
monday stephen moga and will stacy will be talking about photography and its role in
documenting and rebuilding new orleans today's speaker is wendy e wald
wendy has an mit connection she graduated from antioch college and
then came to mit to study photography with minor white it was a really wonderful
program legendary program it was uh and i look forward to hearing more about
that maybe not part of this lecture but um wendy has been as you saw from the
poster has been working with children in her photography
for most of her career and her talk tonight is titled secret games collaborations with
children for her work in working with children
in photographing their own place and linking that
uh to education and literacy uh wendy has is a recipient of many
awards for this work including the macarthur fellowship so thank you for coming this evening and
welcome wendy thank you all right i'm gonna sit down and i wish
i was sitting there instead of up here but um anyway
so um i thought that what might be useful is to kind of look at at
different phases of my work because i have been since 1969
you know since i was here um working collaboratively and at that
time that wasn't something that um people did now it's it's somewhat of
a fashion in in in the art world um but so i'm i'm going to start with with
the most recent project that i'm working on right now and um
it's in margate england and i'm also going to read little bits of things that
that that people have said that i've worked with to give you more of a context for for
the work and this is i'm going to read first something that ali rasa
one of my collaborators in margate england said in this short world of two days why do
you walk so proudly even if you become a suleiman in the end you will still die
i wish for the rights of all children of the world to be respected i hope for a bright future for all
children my name is ali rasa i was born in afghanistan ghazni
because of problems in afghanistan i could not continue my life there i really don't want to tell anything
about it there was chaos in afghanistan my life was in danger i wanted to get away from all the pain i had suffered to
live in a free country so margate
is a seaside town which is down at the heels and
it's cold it was once a grand place
but now there are a lot of decrepit edwardian hotels most of them are empty and boarded up
and but for the past for quite a few years
the british home office has been housing asylum seekers in in these hotels in in
margate um and um also it's become a place for people in
britain to start their lives over again um people who who may be from northern ireland or who
were um fleeing a situation in in domestic violence um because there's all
this temporary housing there um so um i did a project where i worked with um a
number of of children um both
asylum seekers and and and british children trying to look at the the idea
of asylum and the idea of starting one's life over and to expand the idea the
traditional idea of asylum and also i wanted to make present
these people in this community who are they're more than ignored they're people
don't really accept that they're there um there's a lot of tension um they
think that asylum seekers are getting a free ride um they don't want them housed in their
community so um i made portraits of
of each of the children i was working with um their faces uh with a four by five the the backs of
their heads and the objects they brought with them i also um
taught them how to use polaroid positive negative film
to photograph their impressions of their new environment they made maps of places
they had come from and maps of their new home and
and then i also made interviews with them and you see along the side are are the words that they have
they have written um and then the first group we put along the um
uh the sea wall um and there were about six
young peoples suites of these photographs and then in may i'm i'm going to go back and and
these a new group of images are going to go up but more into town
now one thing about doing work like this obviously it is very public and um
unfortunately after while we were hanging this first set of images the um
the tube was bombed in in london and so the situation became more more
tense and a week after we put up the images
two of them were petrol bombed there was a suite of images of a
girl from south africa um and her
face and the back of her head were burned but the objects were um were left alone and the objects were
her flip-flops and a copy of the principles of islam
um i also at at at that point um
i was a linked to a national front
website the national front is the fascist party in in england
and there were it was lots of all around these they're appeared fascist graffiti
so it's going to be interesting to go back now that time has passed
and and see what the reception of the second wave is is going to be
but um this is a girl who came from the congo
and she uh and her family have
since gone underground um they
their appeals their initial appeals for asylum were turned down and they became nervous and went
underground this is a boy named yuri from belarus
and he chose his religious icons for me to photograph and
yuri was a very a difficult kid to work with very
emotional very attached to to me and my co-workers
it was difficult to leave in the evening without a very squeezing hug from him
and when we left it was it was very sad um i worked with
them for um for a number of weeks and they were housed in a hotel
um that called the nayland rock hotel which was
a place where t.s eliot wrote part of the wasteland and it was the the
grand old hotel in the in the community
and it was an amazing place because there were people from all over the world
there coming and going um and some six months later um
yuri and his mother were moved um they were given a house um
an apartment um in the north of england and i went to visit him and he was a totally
transformed person no longer was was he clingy and he was
confident he spoke english he was going to school he had changed his name to george
and it was an incredible transformation then a couple of months later when i
went back to england i called his mother again and i said how are you
and they all have cell phones um and i said and she said well 50 50.
um because her english wasn't so good and they had been
they they hadn't gotten one of their papers in on time they had been removed from from their apartment and put in a
detention center um and were waiting in a um
we're in a house in a hotel near the airport the day that i called them and
so i arranged to meet with them the next day and um at their hotel and when i called again i
never got them again so i can only assume that they were deported
and this is ali raisa from afghanistan and he's
going to school and doing fine but not without a very difficult passage he came out of
afghanistan by himself he lost everybody in his family
and so initially i worked with them they couldn't speak english and i did interviews with them and then by the
time that i met with them again they could speak english so their initial interviews were translated
and then they picked um passages that they wanted to place on their portraits
and um this is zakiya's and these are the ones that were burned um
she's a 10 10 year she's a 10 year old girl who actually lives in in the town
with with her family they moved and settled in in margate
and we also as um part of the uh launch of the initial
images um the the children worked with a local artist
to um create a um an insta installations um with their
photographs and their as you can see their suitcases this is zakiya's and um those are her flip-flops when she was
little that she brought with her from south africa and her doll etc
and i initially came to the first time i worked on this scale was in richmond virginia
and i was invited by virginia commonwealth university
and the local community that surrounds vcu
to do a project there was a series of um discussions
about communities in crisis and uh the um the carver community which is
adjacent to vcu is a very poor community historically
while i was there there was a dead body found in the in
the um in the foyer there was lots of uh
drug activity because 95 cut through the community
and there was a fire that destroyed quite a few homes that was started at vcu
they were building a new building and didn't have the correct permits and
there was some problems with how they were building and so the
it actually was the one of the art buildings caught on fire and then the fire jumped over the
the street that separates the community from um
from vcu and burnt down quite a few of the homes my project there was to
create these portraits in between vcu and
and the carver community um both as a um
as an homage or as a uh to show the people in the community
plus the people outside the community who actually lived in that community and
the community was very excited about having images of its young people
um this size on on homes and on on pieces
of the university this is on the home of one of the community leaders
this is on on a business that is is between the two communities
so this boy has chosen as an object to represent his community his
mother's yearbook and and has chosen to write this on the back
of his head
and this is the old jefferson clothing store which is
right on the edge of the community and um cevante chose his his um
grandmother's african drum to represent his community
and i love the fact that it's on this building with the bust of
jefferson
but for me i had always worked inside in galleries and this was a
um you know a different way of collaborating with with the community
not only collaborating um to make the work but also in a way that
they could participate in in the viewing of it and it could change their community
these stayed up for a year and a half the community didn't want them to be
taken down and they have them now and and they're building a community center and they want to put them up in the
community center we were worried when we put them up that they um
they would be written on because there's a good bit of graffiti around but that never happened and uh
sometimes people would think that the writing on that the kids did was actually graffiti would call up and say
hey you better go look at those banners so people were very protective
of it and then the community itself raised money to do a book
as well but it was a completely different community than the one in
in england was a community that's in pieces um
this was the african-american community was united had actually fought against the university to remain a residential
community so at this point the university has to ask the community
permission to move into the neighborhood and so it's it's been a pretty pretty
successful partnership recently
and this is on the vcu parking lot
but i started uh working in kentucky
well i actually started working before that but in in the early 70s
and i worked in appalachia and
this is a self-portrait that one of my students took and it's called it's a picture of me
with a statue behind me so anyway just kind of back up a little bit
when i started working
i was really interested in how people use images and what are they what are they for
and does that change actually what the images are and
when i when i had a son um 10 years ago and
when he was going into kindergarten i had to um decide we had to decide
whether he was going to go into pre-kindergarten or kindergarten i wanted him to go into pre-kindergarten
and um but they asked him to make a drawing to determine whether he should
which kindergarten he should go in and he made a kindergarten of a man with a heart and a soul and he was i guess he
was three or four at the time and they hadn't seen a drawing like that
of a that a child that like that age had made so they decided that he needed to go
into the into the kindergarten um and then when he started out
um all the rooms and you probably have seen this had little drawings had little cutouts
with each of the kids names on them well in his room they had owls that were brown and
the names were written in black on these brown owls and they were very difficult to read
and inside the classroom the same thing they had cubbies with these owls high up with their names written on them and and
for kids who are just starting to read it was impossible to
decipher and for kids also i think are are very complex visual
thinkers and when people start to
work with kids beyond kindergarten they really don't think much about the visual culture
of childhood sometimes are art and rich art enrichment classes but
they don't approach the sophistication that kids are really capable of
and they see what's around them they process it i can remember my my son when he was
very very little looking looking at an object and then looking at it at a 2d
representation of it and just being fascinated you know even before that he he could talk um so really my art has
kind of grown out of certain questions that that come out of um
that kind of thinking about that kind of representation and i since i've worked
over 30 years in all different places um i've seen many different things and
so i'm i am an artist but my work is really intertwined with with being a teacher um
and so that's why i call it secret games because really it's the kids and i are
playing are playing visual games and and i know what they're capable of
um and um and they they're not censoring themselves in the way that that adults
do and also is very interested about what are the distinctions between things what
what is the distinction between child and adult and photographer and subject and
documentary photography and art and and and in schools you know how are
schools how is the education in our schools constructed it's largely white middle class
linear thinking it's tidy and it's sort of dedicated to doing
things the right way but although many of the students
in american classrooms are neither white nor middle class
so i what i was interested in was finding ways of bringing my students world into the classroom
and but the pictures i began to see were not pictures that i'd seen before
of of children um they are very different than
in a quote innocent um portrayals of
of children who might be adorable in middle class um tableaus or or
victims of poverty or war um and i think that these things are sort
of packaged ideas of of childhood and that's not what what i was seeing
and for example this is this is a
photograph by ruby cornet and it's a self-portrait and it's called i asked my sister to
take a picture of me on easter morning
and this is a picture that freddie childers took of of himself i mean he probably set it up and then
asked his brother or sister to actually shoot it and it's called self-portrait with a
picture of my biggest brother everett who killed himself when he came back from vietnam
and um freddie was six at the time he was in first grade
um and um the picture he's holding of his brother was actually when his brother was six as
well and freddie um went to a one-room school
it was one of two one one room schools still left in in kentucky at that point
um and there were eight grades and uh the kids were working with with polaroid
cameras um and we didn't have a dark room at that point because there was no place in the
one room there was just a wood a wood stove in the middle for heat
so the first thing i would do let me go back to this the
first thing i would do would be to ask them to make self-portraits this is kind of i started
working there in i think 19
1975 and i was developing as a way of working within schools
at that point and i discovered that if you um teach writing
along with photography that they'll the teachers and schools will let you do pretty much whatever you want to do
and so it was a strategy i was much more interested in the images
i and i also thought the writing could help the students focus on what they
would take so they wouldn't you know just run off home with the camera without any idea
well i sort of discovered that that was actually a pretty good idea and that you could go both ways
that the kids could also write after they had the pictures because as you know photography is is an art of of
detail and what kids have trouble with when they're learning how to write is writing from
details and also it was a way of bringing their own homes and the things that were
important to them into the classroom as subject matter
so the second thing i would ask them to do was to photograph their families
which was something they loved and loved to do and this uh photograph is called mommy and daddy
by martha campbell and these kids were um this is from not
from the one room school it's it's from a small consolidated school
and these kids were taking instamatic cameras home which
they were a little cassette with 126 films wonderful films plus x
film um and you would it had 12 shots in it you'd put this cassette in the back of
the instamatic and close it up and if another kid came along and opened the back
it was fine only the shot that that was about to be exposed would be ruined
and then they brought the film back into the classroom and i had built a dark room in
there it was basically a box with a plastic black plastic top on it
and they would develop in and print and i was fortunate to be able to work with these kids some of these kids for
five years so i saw them from when they were in the fourth grade through the eighth grade
um and then we we eventually did this book together
um so also another thing that was very important to these kids were animals
they were rural kids there they were they the animals were pets but they were
also food and um this picture is is uh called my daddy is
measuring our hog um by joy ingram and um thanksgiving is traditionally
butchering time so this was taken in november
and one of the things that i i am the oldest of six kids um i was
around a lot of kids in kentucky my neighbors and i often watched them and thought
about um their intense creativity when when they're playing and
was wondering how i could access that photographically
and so i kind of struck on the idea of asking them to photograph their dreams
as kind of being a way that i could i could put it that they might understand
um and so to start off we went in our dark room and uh
turned out the the light in there and and told each other dreams and there were some scary dreams and uh to create
a um an atmosphere that was um comfortable for them to to share
their dreams with each other um and then i asked them to make images of
of those things and um for some kids it was like you know just turning on the light they
they knew exactly what they wanted to do and for other kids it was something that was
very very difficult this is by allen shepherds and it's called i
dreamed i killed my best friend ricky dixon and alan and ricky
had had a um fight over um knives um they'd swap
hunting knives because all these kids had um had knives and a lot of them actually
had guns too for hunting and they each thought the other one had
tricked them so they had stopped talking and
alan had this dream about ricky and then asked ricky to
enact it for him and in the in the making of the photograph the two of them
made up um and continued their friendship
um this is by denise dixon who
is the most talented student i've ever worked with i don't know what has happened to her she moved away
from the mountains and this is called i am dolly parton
and denise's only photographs pretty much were self-portraits and photographs of her
twin brothers who were younger than she was but she did many self-portraits
this is another one called a girl the girl with the snake around her i am the girl with the snake around her her
neck and i don't know if you guys know who cindy sherman is do you know who she is
well i always say that denise did these before cindy sherman did her pictures
only denise really they're more moving to me because denise really believes she's those people in in
that moment um and this is another one of her pictures
of and it's called um philip and jamie are creatures from outer space in their
spaceship and um she worked very hard to create the
effects that she wanted there's nothing unintentional about any of this
and you can see if you look at at her contact sheets she experimented with a lot of different
materials before she got the stockings right to get that that look
and she made some very long complicated dreams too um
and we had an exhibition at the university of kentucky um we had many exhibitions we had one in the
international center of photography and in chicago and
but the the one at the university of kentucky um we took most of the kids and denise's
mother came as well because she was very proud of denise's photography
and um during the opening she stood next to that picture the whole time to tell anyone who looked at it that her kids
really didn't look that way but um
you know there's something i knew that there was something about these pictures that i hadn't seen in in other photographs
before either photographs of of appalachia or
actually earlier i worked in canada they were different than documentary
pictures um and uh it's interesting now um
i'm starting to get because of the internet get back in touch with a lot of these people who are now
in in their 40s and um it's uh interesting to hear
you know what what that kind of meant to them or or how it fit into their
um into their lives and we're about to reprint the book which which was now
25 years ago i guess that we did it
um and then i i went to i did lots of things but but i went to
india in the early 90s
and for me that was a very important experience because i i lived in a village
in gujarat and i worked with kids
20 kids in that village and those kids didn't have any pictures
nobody in the village had any pictures there were no newspapers with pictures there were no books with pictures
there were no snapshots the images that there were were
laminated um colorful laminated pictures of the gods that were on their
houses and so
when i started working i had to everybody wanted to be involved
and i was working with a um a local organization and um and the elders in
the village said that they thought that i should um create a um a kind of test to see who should who
should be in the class and so i asked each one of
of the kids what they wanted to take pictures of
why they wanted to take pictures and to look through my camera and tell me what they could see
and what i started discovering was that they all said they wanted to
photograph the gods and um so
i was really perplexed and as as were the people from the community who not from the community but from the
organization who were working with me and finally we said okay well so what is a photo
and which was the word that was being used in gujarati and
they showed us the laminated pictures of the gods so what i had to do
which was such a privilege to be able to do was to was to tell them to show them what a
camera could do and i had fortunately had polaroid positive negative film
so i could i took a picture of each one of them and showed them the negative and gave
them the the print um and i just asked each one of them to sit how they wanted to sit so
i did a whole series of pictures of them and it was the first time they'd looked at the camera and the first time you know the camera had had looked at them
and i was just doing it as a teaching tool um but then later on i realized that
there was a kind of power to um to the images um because of that you
know first intense gaze and so i used them in subsequently in a book that i did
and then i paired paired them with interviews i did with the kids
at the end of the project um and this is has moop one of the kids and
i'll just read you a little tiny bit of of uh i think if i can find it
of one because it also context became very important for these images um
i you know needed to explain really who these kids were not
that just that they were taking pictures but who they were was as important as as
what they were taking pictures of um so he's 14 and uh a member of the farmer
cast and he says i got married two months ago it was a nice day we all went to my
wife's village on a tractor no one danced but people sang i enjoyed it
i married golly from vasana near doda my sister married a fellow from vasana
and when we visited i'd see golly fetching water i had no idea that i would marry her but
she knew i didn't even know her name when i got engaged golly's relatives
came here to the village her father brought me a turban a letter and a piece of paper
then he put a coconut in my hand and brought me a bowl of butter to drink her father's a rich man so she brought
lots of money and gold ornaments with her golly wears village skirts and sarees
she's tall maybe i'll grow to be a tall fella like her but short boys get married too
she's 13 and i'm 14. i like her she's good-natured and good-looking i took
four or five pictures of her standing by the door i'd like to bring her to photography class but she'll feel shy
she doesn't fight with me she always respects me and when she doesn't i'll send her away
eventually i'll go to my father-in-law's place to live they have a scooter and two cycles over there i'll need a kid
also i want only one son no both a son and a daughter
i'll name the boy mahesh in the girl wendy i don't have any brothers and
sisters at home so i like it when she comes to say i have three sisters but they are
married one brother died in an accident and one drowned he was a lame fellow neither of his legs
worked when he walked to the fields on crutches he always passed a dump one day it was filled with water and he
fell into it and drowned i dream about my brothers that died so at night i covered myself with the
blanket to keep away the dreams when my heart beats the dream comes out
it shouts from the whole body i'm coming out and then it comes out on diwali i dreamed that i went up to
the sun in a balloon i saw two goats standing on the edge of the sun and they tried to butt me away
we are all dreaming but in the morning when we open our eyes the dreams are all gone last night i dreamed i had a girl in my
pocket
so the the form of the book also became very important to me as as a way of um
of contextualizing um the images um and there on the left
you see one of the photos and uh and then i wrote about the experience of
of working together um and um
each of the sections was uh was divided by
by prayers um that were um used in the process of working together and and this is um
this is a prayer which was recited at the dedication of the dark room because we built a dark room
um there were only mud houses so we um we built a
cinderblock darkroom with a tin roof um uh in the barber's front yard the
barber was one of the village elders and um he
agreed to let us have the that piece of land for 10 years
rent free if at the end of the 10 years he could have the building
and so it was a it was a big day when when the dark room was open was opened and
it was lots of um ceremony and speeches and and this was this was part of it
and another thing that was it was quite remarkable about these kids is i
it was very difficult for them to photograph there because everybody wanted their photograph to be taken
and so it was hard for them to isolate the figure or isolate something
and so towards the end of the project they spontaneously some of the kids
started cutting up the images and this is the result of
one of those projects but they they used everything every bit of the the process the uh the paper that
that um that wrapped around the film the box um the leader
um and uh i got books um with archival paper um from gandhi's
ashram for for them to to work on so it
it was a case of sort of following where they wanted to go and then eventually when i did do this
book which is called i dreamed i had a girl in my pocket um there was a section of my photographs the section of their
photographs um so it was really about this collaboration it was about the village
but it was all also about how we had worked together um and so the the picture on the right
is my picture the picture on the left is um uh sajon's picture and um
she's photographed the wedding of the girl whose face is cut off in the front and the boy in the center of the picture
and so they just want to say one more thing one of
the great things about working with them is that they really
believed strongly that making an image was giving respect and
so every piece of the process also they related to that and when
they developed film when they would agitate the film they would pray because it reminded them of of the
of the rd which is part part of the the prayer ceremony and
in the dark room we had a a bulb that we painted red for our safe
light and they called that god's bulb but it was it was a privilege for me to
get to understand photography through their eyes and to have to explain it from
um from the basic viewpoint of making of giving
respect by making an image and then i went to uh polaroid sent me
to mexico um and um to do
create an exhibition um and i this was um
this actually i think was in 92 and i
worked in four different communities two indigenous indigenous communities and
two um latino or or two communities of spanish descent
um in chiapas and it was the year before the the
revolt in chiapas and it was the first time i
asked kids actually to use positive negative film i thought it would be something that would be very difficult
because with these cameras you have to measure the distance and
you know you can't see it and also they had to carry a bucket of
sodium sulfite with them when they shot to put the negatives in it was pretty
complicated what i found however is that's a great thing to do
because the kids had to work hard to learn how to command the material
and um they were certainly up to it and it slowed their process down so they
could think about what it was that they were going to do this is a photograph by juan jesus
murillo and it's called here's my cousin miri with
the skulls and fruit for the day of the dead i always have asked the kids to make
titles for their pictures um with the idea that these photographs are
going to be seen by people and then if you make
any kind of verbal context for a photograph then you can direct people to what it is
that you want them to see to further give them control over over the image
um and juan jesus is actually um
one of the better photographers and he was blind in one eye and had a hard time seeing out of the
other eye and he said what he really liked about
taking pictures was that when kids would talk about experiences that they'd had together
they would always say oh you remember when we saw that oh you remember that guy remember what he looked like and
those weren't things he could those weren't common memories he could have because he didn't see the same
things and so by having the photographs he could go
back and talk with his friends and also look closely and see some of the things that they that they were
seeing
and this is by teresa lopez called my dog walking in the patio
and of course every different camera different kind of film um affected the the process the practice
the the the photographs but also the process of working together um
this is by nicassio perez and it's called my sister is braiding her hair
and this is by vladimir stalin because
and it's called the hens are going into the kitchen
so here again animals um
this one is called my sister carrying the water and it's by luis hernandez gomez
and for a lot of these kids they didn't have any photographs they'd never had any photographs
this is one of my favorite photographs of old times i think
and it's by sebastian gomez hernandez and it's called the devil is spying on the girls
and i have no idea how he was able to make that you know how the kid got because i wasn't there you know when
these were made um how the kid got up there but
in mayan culture dreams are extremely important
whatever happens in in a dream is considered as real as waking reality
so when i asked when i let them know that we would be um
i would be asking them to to photograph dreams they were very excited and also i had to say it's fun to see us and and
the next day they they arrived with um masks that they had made and this is one
of the masks they didn't have any materials so the the masks were made from the back of cracker boxes
um and they're you know beautiful masks and but i said well you know why did you um
make the horns coming out of the the jaw why why didn't they come out of the you know the top of the head and he said oh
i don't know it just looked good to me that way um and then later um i was actually
sharing a um a house with an anthropologist and
she pointed out to me images in the mine glyphs where
the these things of that shape come out of the jaws and then i began to think about
well you know where do these ideas come from they um they are embedded in the visual ideas
are embedded in the culture um and uh anything that that a child comes up with
is for a reason um
and this is uh called wolfman and his enemy by javier bautista

in this case photography turned out to be something more it began when we allowed an outsider to
see behind the veil then assuming the role of hunters put us in another realm and gave us a place to
stand that was powerful enough to alter the male controlled orbits we move in
when we took our cameras into the street people reacted with sincerity and entertain new possibilities
the bodies they had lived in so long open to whatever experiences they might encounter
they seemed oblivious to the dangers of intrusion or captivity they opened up and posed happily
smiling at the camera's charm and at our courage in openly pursuing stories in
circumstances that are ordinarily closed by posing they allowed us to steal their
souls and in the very act of announcing our power we women gained power over the men
and this is a picture that that raja took of of herself and it was great working with these women um
